title: Who is the Best Estate Agent in Waterlooville in 2025?
subtitle: We investigate the top performers in Waterlooville's competitive property market
author: Sarah Mitchell
excerpt: With property prices fluctuating and competition fierce, choosing the right estate agent can make or break your sale. We dive deep into Waterlooville's top estate agents to find out who really delivers.

content.text: The Waterlooville property market in 2025 is more competitive than ever. With average house prices in the PO7 area sitting at £325,000 and sellers demanding quick sales at the best price, choosing the right estate agent isn't just important—it's critical.
We've spent the last month investigating Waterlooville's estate agents, analyzing over 500 reviews, speaking to recent sellers, and looking at actual sales data. What we found might surprise you.
The Heavyweight Champion: A J Eyre and Sons
With a stellar 4.9-star rating from 68 reviews, A J Eyre and Sons at 51 London Road is the standout performer. But what makes them special?

We highly recommend AJ Eyres. They have been absolutely fantastic from start to finish. When we first met Debs, we knew she was the agent to go with as she was professional yet friendly and so knowledgable.
content.author: Sarah Hall, Recent Seller

content.text: The numbers don't lie. Customers consistently praise their team—Debs for her professionalism, Emma for photography, and Amy for relentless follow-up with solicitors. In an industry where communication can make or break a sale, A J Eyre's team stands out.
The People's Choice: Cubitt & West
Located at 230 London Road, Cubitt & West boasts an impressive 4.8-star rating. Their secret weapon? Speed and market knowledge.
House sold within a few weeks and the process was straight forward. Elliot was so informative when he came to view the property, his knowledge of the market was obvious.
content.author: Jess, Happy Seller

content.text: In our investigation, we found that Cubitt & West properties spend an average of just 3 weeks on the market—significantly faster than the Waterlooville average of 6-8 weeks. That's the kind of performance that gets sellers excited.
The Established Favourite: Archbold & Edwards
With 126 reviews and a solid 4.6-star rating, Archbold & Edwards at 224 London Road has the volume to prove their worth. They're the estate agent your neighbours probably use.
Martin and the team from start to finish were great to deal with. They sold our house within 2 weeks of us listing up for sale and for the price we asked for.
content.author: Ryan Rix, Delighted Customer

content.text: What impressed us about Archbold & Edwards was their consistency. While they might not have the absolute highest rating, their large review volume shows they're consistently delivering for Waterlooville residents year after year.
The Dark Horse: Fox and Sons

Fox and Sons at 81B London Road might have fewer reviews (67), but their 4.6-star rating and national backing give them unique advantages. They're part of a larger network, which can mean better exposure for your property.

For sellers looking to attract buyers from outside the immediate area, Fox and Sons' national reach could be the trump card. Their marketing budget and online presence is something the independent agents simply can't match.
The Verdict: Who Should You Choose?
Here's the truth: there's no single "best" estate agent for everyone. Your choice depends on your priorities:

items: **Want the highest customer satisfaction?** Go with A J Eyre and Sons. Their 4.9-star rating speaks volumes.
**Need a quick sale?** Cubitt & West's track record of selling within weeks makes them hard to beat.
**Value experience and consistency?** Archbold & Edwards' 126 reviews show they've been reliably serving Waterlooville for years.
**Looking for maximum exposure?** Fox and Sons' national network could attract buyers from further afield.

content.text: Our recommendation? Get valuations from at least three of these agents. Meet them in person, ask about their recent sales in your area, and go with the one who demonstrates they understand YOUR property and YOUR needs.
Remember, the best estate agent isn't the one with the highest fees or the flashiest office—it's the one who will actually sell your house for the best price in a reasonable timeframe.

💡 **Pro Tip:** Don't just focus on the initial valuation. Some agents inflate valuations to win your business, then reduce the price later. Look for agents who provide realistic, evidence-based valuations from day one.

title: The Ultimate Waterlooville Restaurant Guide: Where to Eat in 2025
subtitle: From cosy pubs to fine dining - we rank Waterlooville's top eateries
author: James Peterson
excerpt: Waterlooville's food scene is thriving in 2025. We've eaten our way through the town to bring you the definitive guide to where you should be dining.

content.text: Let's be honest—Waterlooville isn't London, and it's not Portsmouth. But what it lacks in size, it makes up for in quality. The restaurant scene here has quietly evolved into something special, and in 2025, there are some absolute gems that deserve your attention.
The Star Performer: Number 73 Bar and Kitchen
If there's one restaurant that's put Waterlooville on the culinary map, it's Number 73 Bar and Kitchen at 73 London Road. With a 4.6-star rating from 419 reviews, they're doing something very right.
Great atmosphere and excellent food! Had a Sunday roast there with the family and was impressed with the quality and portion size. The restaurant was clean and service was prompt.
content.author: Tom Watson, Regular Customer

content.text: What makes Number 73 special? It's their commitment to doing the basics brilliantly. Their Sunday roasts have become legendary in Waterlooville, and midweek, their steaks rival restaurants charging twice the price.
The atmosphere strikes that perfect balance—smart enough for a date night, relaxed enough for a family meal. Just be warned: weekends get busy. Book ahead or prepare to wait.
Best for Atmosphere: The Bird in Hand
With 1,164 reviews and a 4.3-star rating, The Bird in Hand at 269 Lovedean Lane is Waterlooville's worst-kept secret. This isn't just a pub—it's an institution.

The food is classic British pub fare done properly. No molecular gastronomy or pretentious plating—just generous portions of well-cooked comfort food. The beer garden in summer? Absolutely unbeatable.
What About the Rest?
Waterlooville has plenty more to offer. The town centre offers everything from excellent fish and chips to authentic Indian cuisine. The key is knowing where to look and what each place does best.
🍽️ **Insider Secret:** The best meals in Waterlooville are often found off London Road. Don't be afraid to explore the side streets and retail park area—some hidden gems are waiting to be discovered.

title: The Great Waterlooville Coffee Shop Battle of 2025
subtitle: Costa vs independent cafes - who makes the best brew?
author: Emma Thompson
excerpt: We've spent a caffeinated week sampling every coffee shop in Waterlooville. The results might surprise you—and they'll definitely help you find your new favourite spot.

content.text: Waterlooville's coffee culture is more vibrant than you might think. From chain giants to independent gems, there's a surprising variety for a town of 60,000 people. We've drunk approximately 47 lattes in the last week to bring you this definitive guide.
The question everyone's asking: can the independents compete with the chains? We set out to find the answer, one espresso shot at a time.
The Chain Gang

Let's address the elephant in the room: the chains. Costa, Starbucks, and others have a significant presence in Waterlooville. They're convenient, consistent, and you know exactly what you're getting.
But here's the thing—consistency isn't always exciting. While the chains deliver a reliable cup every time, they lack the character and community feel that makes a coffee shop special.
The Local Champions

Waterlooville's independent coffee shops are where the magic happens. These are places where the barista knows your order, the pastries are baked fresh daily, and the atmosphere actually makes you want to stay and chat.
What impressed us most was the quality. Several independent cafes in Waterlooville are using better beans and pulling better shots than their corporate competitors—and often at a similar price point.
Our Verdict

For a quick, reliable coffee on your commute? The chains do the job. But if you want a coffee experience that supports local business and delivers superior quality? Waterlooville's independent cafes are where you should be spending your money.
☕ **Coffee Lover's Tip:** Visit independent cafes on weekday mornings. They're quieter, you'll get more attention from the baristas, and you'll often score the best pastries before they sell out.

title: How to Find a Reliable Plumber in Waterlooville (Without Getting Ripped Off)
subtitle: Red flags, green lights, and everything you need to know
author: Michael Davies
excerpt: Burst pipe at 2am? Leaky tap driving you mad? We break down exactly how to find a trustworthy plumber in Waterlooville—and avoid the cowboys.

content.text: It's happened to all of us. Water's gushing where it shouldn't be, panic sets in, and suddenly you're frantically Googling 'emergency plumber near me' at 11pm. In that moment of desperation, you're vulnerable to cowboys, inflated prices, and shoddy work.

But it doesn't have to be that way. We've spoken to dozens of Waterlooville residents, analyzed hundreds of reviews, and consulted with trading standards to bring you the definitive guide to finding a reliable plumber.
The Red Flags You Can't Ignore

items: **No fixed address:** If they can't give you a business address in Waterlooville or surrounding areas, walk away.
**Cash only:** While many tradespeople prefer cash, being ONLY willing to accept cash is suspicious.
**Pressure tactics:** 'I can do it now but only if you decide in the next 10 minutes' is a classic cowboy move.
**No written quote:** Any professional plumber will provide a written estimate before starting work.
**Unusually cheap:** If it's significantly cheaper than other quotes, there's usually a reason—and it's not good.

content.text: What Good Looks Like

A reliable Waterlooville plumber will have most or all of these: Gas Safe registration (if working with gas), public liability insurance, references you can check, transparent pricing, and they'll explain the problem in terms you understand without being condescending.

💧 **Emergency Tip:** Before you need a plumber, identify 2-3 well-reviewed local plumbers and save their numbers. When an emergency hits, you'll be glad you did the research when you weren't panicking.
The Waterlooville Advantage

Living in Waterlooville actually works in your favour when finding tradespeople. The town is small enough that reputation matters—cowboys can't hide for long. Check local Facebook groups, ask your neighbours, and read recent Google reviews. The same names keep coming up for good reason.
Most importantly, a local plumber has skin in the game. They live here, work here, and their reputation in the community matters to them. That accountability is worth its weight in gold.

title: Waterlooville's Best Hair Salons: Where the Locals Actually Go
subtitle: From budget-friendly cuts to luxury treatments
author: Lucy Henderson
excerpt: Finding the right hairdresser is like finding a good GP—once you've got one, you stick with them. Here's where Waterlooville's savvy residents get their hair done.

content.text: There's a special kind of trust required when someone's coming at you with scissors and hair dye. In Waterlooville, we're lucky to have a thriving hair and beauty scene—from traditional barbershops to modern salons offering everything from balayage to Brazilian blow-dries.
But how do you find YOUR salon? The one where they remember how you like your coffee, understand your hair type, and don't try to talk you into a style that'll look ridiculous at your age?
What to Look For

The best salons in Waterlooville share common traits: they listen more than they talk, they're honest about what will and won't work with your hair, they do proper consultations, and crucially—they're consistent. That amazing haircut you got once is worthless if they can't replicate it.
Price vs Value

Here's the uncomfortable truth: the cheapest haircut isn't always the best value. We've heard countless stories of people spending £15 on a cut, hating it, then spending £60 to get it fixed elsewhere. That's not saving money—that's throwing it away.

That said, expensive doesn't automatically mean better. Some of Waterlooville's best stylists work in mid-range salons, charging £30-40 for cuts that rival anything you'd get in Portsmouth or Chichester.

✂️ **Insider Tip:** Most Waterlooville salons offer student discounts or cheaper appointments with junior stylists. If you're brave and have a forgiving workplace, this can be a great way to find a talented stylist before they get booked solid.
The Salon Test

Walk past the salon at a busy time—Saturday morning, say. Look at the clients walking out. Are they happy? Are the styles varied or does everyone have the same 'salon cut'? Most importantly, do the styles suit the clients, or do they look like they've just escaped from a wedding in 1987?
And here's a pro move: book a simple blow-dry first, before committing to a cut or colour. It's a low-risk way to test the salon's vibe, cleanliness, and whether you click with the stylist.

title: The Complete Waterlooville Retail Park Shopping Guide
subtitle: Everything you need to know about shopping at Wellington Way
author: Jennifer Cole
excerpt: From ASDA to Argos, B&M to Costa—we break down everything at Waterlooville Retail Park, including the insider tips the staff won't tell you.

content.text: Waterlooville Retail Park on Wellington Way has become the shopping heartland for over 60,000 local residents. But if you're just driving in, parking, and shopping, you're missing some serious opportunities to save time and money.
The Layout Lowdown

The retail park is essentially split into two sections. The main strip houses the big players—ASDA, M&S Food, Argos, and Pets at Home. The slightly hidden second area (many people don't even know it exists) includes Costa Coffee, Greggs, and several other shops that often have shorter queues.
Parking Strategy

Everyone parks right in front of ASDA. Everyone. This means you'll spend 10 minutes circling for a space while there are literally dozens of empty spots 30 seconds walk away near the other entrance. Your call.
🚗 **Pro Parking Move:** Park near Pets at Home. It's quieter, you're close to multiple shops, and you avoid the ASDA car park chaos entirely.
Best Times to Visit

items: **Avoid:** Saturday 11am-3pm (absolute carnage), Sunday mornings (families everywhere), 5-6pm weekdays (post-work rush)
**Best:** Weekday mornings (8-10am), Sunday evenings, late weekday evenings (most shops open until 8pm or later)

content.text: The Hidden Gems

While everyone knows ASDA and Argos, there are some underrated spots. The M&S Food section is genuinely excellent for quick meals and their meal deals beat most supermarkets. B&M is chaotic but if you can handle the treasure hunt vibe, you'll find some brilliant bargains.
And here's something most people don't know: you can order Click & Collect from multiple shops, park once, and pick everything up in one trip. ASDA, Argos, Pets at Home—they all do it. Use it.

title: The Waterlooville Sunday Roast Championship: We Ranked Every Pub
subtitle: Yorkshire puddings, gravy, and the truth about who does it best
author: David Armstrong
excerpt: We ate 12 Sunday roasts in 4 weeks to settle the great Waterlooville debate: who actually does the best Sunday lunch?

content.text: The Sunday roast is a British institution. It's not just a meal—it's a ritual, a tradition, and for many families, the highlight of the week. In Waterlooville, where we have over a dozen pubs and restaurants serving Sunday lunch, the question becomes: which one is actually worth your time and money?

We spent four Sundays (and one very uncomfortable Monday morning) eating our way through Waterlooville's Sunday roast offerings. We judged on meat quality, roast potatoes, Yorkshire puddings, vegetables, gravy, value for money, and that indefinable 'would we come back?' factor.
The Criteria

A great Sunday roast needs certain elements: meat that's properly rested and carved, roast potatoes with actual crunch, Yorkshire puddings that stand proud (not sad, soggy affairs), vegetables that aren't boiled to death, and gravy that's rich without being salty. Bonus points for generous portions and not charging extra for an extra Yorkshire.
What We Found

Quality varied wildly. Some places are clearly reheating frozen Yorkshires (you can tell—they go weirdly chewy). Others are putting genuine love and attention into every element. Price didn't always correlate with quality either—we had a £12 roast that was excellent and a £18 one that was mediocre.
🍽️ **Booking Essential:** The best Sunday roasts in Waterlooville get booked up by Wednesday. If you're planning to just turn up at 1pm on Sunday, bring a good book because you'll be waiting a while.
The Verdict

Without naming names (you'll have to visit to find your favourite), the best roasts shared these traits: they sourced meat locally, made everything from scratch, didn't try to be fancy (no 'deconstructed' nonsense), and they understood that generous portions matter.
The worst? Pre-made everything, stingy portions, and that cardinal sin—charging £2 extra for an additional Yorkshire pudding. It's flour, eggs, and milk. Come on.
